history.content:
I'd say it's definitely doable and if you have limited time left at Berkeley, to go for it. The time commitment for CS 70 varies widely depending on how comfortable you are with discrete math and probability (previous contest math experience helps but is not necessary), and expect one problem set a week (may range from 5-20 hours, again based on how long you devote to thinking about the questions). STAT C8 is pretty light if you've taken CS 61A and have something similar to AP Statistics experience from high school, the weekly homework took no more than a few hours and the projects a few more. I have not personally taken EE16B but I heard the workload is pretty hefty, so, to be honest, I'd expect that to have the most "required" work.

However, you definitely understand your own background and strengths better than I do, so make the decision that you are most comfortable with! In my consideration, I weighed the possibilities of taking future classes more heavily than doing extremely well in each course, so up to you!

children.subject:
Wow, no need to be sorry at all. This was the kind of insight I needed and helps a lot, like for real, I really do appreciate taking the time out of your day to write such a detailed response!

If you don't mind me asking, did you prep before taking 70? If you didn't prep, do you think watching most of the lectures from past semesters would have helped you more, or do you think it wouldn't have helped much? If you did prep, based on your response, I'd probably replace 16B, but I'm not sure what class to pick. I was thinking about taking 61C since I have the equivalent done, and maybe take it pass or no pass depending on how the class is going, but I'm not quite sure at all. Any suggestions would be great on classes to replace 16B and thanks again.

I did not prep before 70 at all. You can definitely watch lectures if you want so that you can preface the material, however the notes are excellent and probably a better resource to go to. The main thing in this class is getting used to the difficulty of the problems and the kinds of problems the exams ask. In the iteration of the course I took, exams were 90% of the grade, so being able to do those exam questions/homework questions is important. 

As for a replacement for 16B, that's tough. I haven't done 61C myself though I wouldn't consider that a "lower workload" alternative by any means. it's definitely another time taking class. Is it more time consuming than 16B? I can't say since I haven't done. A lot of my friends have done 61C + 70 so its definitely a common combo to do. Can you afford to replace 16B with a breadth, or do you have to have another technical in there to finish in time?

Sorry for the late reply. I have four semesters left here including this upcoming Spring semester. I've finished my breadth and the university requirements(American cultures, American history, etc). So the only classes left are technicals. Say if I was able to declare we need 20 units of upper div classes and 7 units of upper div tech electives which we can probably kill two birds with one stone. 

Spring 2020 Plan:

-16B, 70, Data8

Summer 2020:

-61B(preferred class) or 16B(if necessary)

Fall 2020:

-2 upper div techs ~ 8 units 

along with 61C --> Plan 1 (preferred)

-3 upper div techs ~ 12 units --> Plan 2

Spring 2021(last semester):

-3 upper div techs ~ 12 units

I'm assuming all the 7 units of upper div tech electives can be fulfilled with CS and EECS classes. So yeah, it's kinda crunched on time if I move 16B to another semester. Also, considering that I really want to take 61B and 61C because the way Berkeley teaches CS is just incomparable with my CC, especially considering the fact that 61B and 61C are fundamentals of CS. Thanks again for all your help.

perspective from someone who just did 16B (w/Sahai) + 70 + Data8 this semester:

 Do this schedule only if you feel you are mathematically mature. You have limited time for sure, but you also want to be able to declare. 16B takes a lot of time out of your schedule simply because the problem sets are insanely long. Some of the content can be difficult and require time to spend on it, though nowhere near the time I had to put into 70. Labs are much much longer than 16A labs. My partner and I (same partner for 16A and 16B) would be done with 16A labs in under 1.5 hours each time. For 16B, we never finished under 2 hours and pretty much every lab beyond the 2nd took the full 3 hours. And when you get to the car, sometimes we need extra time beyond the 3 hours, and that’s time taken away from 70
Potentially. 

As the student answer says above, Data8 isn’t really too bad though I can say it’s gotten harder in recent semesters so just be careful not to treat it like a breadth. As I was taking practice Data8 exams in preparation for the midterm and final, I noticed each exam got harder as the semesters went on, including the actual exams I took this semester in the class. It’s certainly easier if you’ve done 61A (like I have) but the exams have become increasingly more stat heavy. 

As to your question about getting the most out of each class. Unfortunately I wasn’t able to. Having 70, 16B, and data8, I don’t think I was able to get out of 16B what that class has to offer. Same with some of the intro to ML in Data8 towards the end of the semester. All because of 70 the time I had to put into 70. But that is just for me, because I would say I’m not mathematically mature for the kind of math 70 deals with. 

I don’t know how easily you pick up things, so I can’t say for you, but personally for me, I would say I’m average and not one of the “super brilliant at probability and discrete math” people. Meaning with 70, I would have to spend hours reading notes over and over again for something to finally stick in my brain. even with this, Homework’s were still hard and I still always did below the mean on exams, but that’s because I would say I don’t have the mathematical maturity to do these exams. I ended with a B in 70 (the lowest I needed to declare). 

However I know one person who did these 3 and did just fine with getting some form of A grade in all 3, but because they are able to understand things more quickly And more mathematically mature than I am. It all depends on person to person, and this could very well be you. Sorry for the ramble, just wanted to give as detailed of an opinion as I could. Hope this helps and I’m happy to answer any questions.

history.content:
Hi,

Next semester I will be taking CS70, EECS16B, and STATC8, and I need a B+ in 70 to declare, but I was wondering if this load would be doable. Last semester I found the workload of 61A and 16A to be doable/comfortable, and I made some mistakes, which I hope to correct this upcoming semester(I mentioned this in case it would be helpful in answering this question). I don't want to overload myself because I want to make the most of my classes like most if not all students so do you think I should take 16B or STAT C8 some other semester and replace it with two decals or maybe some other class(any recommended classes would be much appreciated also I have completed my breadth)? Or just keep what I have? Again just for reference, I'm planning to take 61B during the summer. I don't need it to declare, but I wanted to take it to make sure I understand the fundamentals well. For reference, it's going to be my second semester here, and I'm a transfer student, so I have limited time here, unfortunately. I would really appreciate any advice and suggestions! Thanks!
history.subject: Advice on next semester schedule
